oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Attractiveness of Solenopsis Ants (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) to Assorted Sugars and Oils
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Whitney, Stephen Roy
Brand, Ashleigh
Chambers, Cross
Flaherty, Elyssa
Maya, Marla
Roybal, Makenzie
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fire ants (Solenopsis spp.) are bothersome insects to both humans and the environment alike. Due to their prevalence in areas near human habitation, we sought to determine a substance that the ants find attractive that could be used in future control methods. To answer our question, we designed a simple experiment in which Solenopsis sp. specimens were each given the opportunity to choose from a variety of sugars and oils that were presented on a piece of paper in front of them. It was determined that fire ants have a stronger attraction to substances higher in fatty acids, such as cooking oils, than carbohydrates. These results have shown that when devising a home remedy for controlling these insects, individuals would have the most success if they were to use an oil-based product in their control method.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Instars: A Journal of Student Research; Vol. 6 No. 1 (2021): Instars: A Journal of Student Research
